moves.2. Nc3: White develops his knight behind the pawn and takes control of the white central squares.
moves.2... Nf6: Black contests the center and prepares for castling.
moves.3... d5: Initiates a trade of a central pawn for a good knight outpost.
moves.6. Bg2:
Completed the fianchetto. And puts the knight on d5 under fire.
The whole game will revolve around the h1-a8 diagonal.
moves.6... Be6: Protects the knight and develops the white bishop.
moves.7. e3: White prepares d4 and temporarily locks in the dark bishop
moves.7... Be7:
Bb4 is an option but stretches Blacks resources. Black has already a good hold of the center.
Hence Be7 is a good move and enables castling.
moves.8. Nge2:
* enables castling
* develops a knight
* supports the d4 advance
moves.8... O-O: Bring the king to safety before committing oneself to uncertain campaigns.
moves.9... a6: Takes the b5 square from the c3-knight.
moves.10. d4: Here we go! A little central activity.
moves.10... exd4:
Forced: 11.dxe5 would have discovered a third attacker against Nd5
I would have loved 11...e4 but that looses the pawn
moves.11. exd4 Bf6: Put more pressure on the d4 pawn.
moves.12... Nce7:
Ne7 supports Nd5 and enables the advancing of the queen-side pawns.

My long term target is the isolated pawn on d4
moves.13... Nxc3: which gives me an excellent outpost on c4 and releases the pressure on d5.
moves.14. bxc3 Bc4:
Alternatives:
c6 to protect my pawns and against d5
or
Bc4!? grabs the outpost and avoids 15.Nxe6
moves.15. Re1:
I wouldn't have played 14...Bc4 against a stronger player:
15.Bxb7 would have been complicated: 15...Rb8 16.Rb1! Bxf1 17.Kxf1
moves.15... c6:
* Protects b7 
* Takes control of d5
* Opens the a5-d8 diagonal for the queen
moves.16... b5:
Natural follow up move - cements the bishop on c4. It will take the knight at least two moves to unsettle the bishop 
Because of Qa4 - with tempo
moves.17. Qb4: The queen is going to c5 which is a good outpost for White.
moves.17... Re8:
Seizes the open file and protects the knight.
I will soon need to move the dark bishop or the queen and I don't want any tactics against the knight
moves.18. Qc5:
Threatens c6.

The queen has a good position here with many possibilities. It is also safe against short term threats from  Black's minor pieces.
moves.19. Nh5:
I think White contemplated 19.Qa7 threatening a6. But this fails after ...a5.
Instead White decided to remove the dark bishop. Black's dark bishop is putting lots of pressure on the c3-d4 pawns.
moves.19... Nd5:
Black don't want to take back with a pawn. Instead  19...Nd5
* protects the bishop twice 
* threatens the c3 pawn. 
* still protects the c6 pawn by blocking the h1-a8 diagonal.

Not bad with one move.
moves.20... Qxf6:
Best is to take back with the queen.
* Makes the queen more active.
* Binds the rooks
* Keeps the pressure on the c3-d4 pawns.
* Protects the c6 pawn so the knight can move.
moves.21. Bxd5: ? Defends c3 by removing the attacker. But this exchanges the light bishop for a knight. This means that the Black's light bishop can seize the h1-a8 diagonal.
moves.21... Bxd5: The exchange ends with the bishop on the deadly h1-a8 diagonal shooting directly against White's king. Black dreams of Qg2 which ends the game.
moves.22. f4: Takes away f3 from the queen.
moves.22... Qf5:
Putting the queen on the same color as the bishop to give me maximum flexibility. 
White it terribly weak on the light squares.
moves.23. Qa3:
The queen retreats:
* defend the second rank (23...Qh3 24.Qb2) 
* threatens a6.
moves.23... Rxe3:
Re3!? My plan is to:
* remove the dark bishop, which is a good defender: a queen invasion Qc2 is blocked by Bf2
* invade on Qc2 - threatening mate on g2.
* check on g1 and gobble up the rook: Kf1 Qg1  Kd2 Qxa1
moves.24. Rxe3: Black is now vulnerable on the e-file, back-rank and a6 and must keep the initiative.
moves.24... Qc2: Qf2# is imminent and cannot be blocked for long.
moves.25. Kf1: Forced, the only way to avoid mate.
moves.25... Qg2+ 26. Ke1 Qg1+ 27. Kd2:
All according to plan when I realized that Qxa1 looses after 28.Re1! and the queen is trapped! I should have calculated one more move before sacrificing the rook.

Actually mate can be forced in 10 moves after 22.Qa3.
A sample variation is 23. Qa3 Qe4 24.Re2 Qh1  25.Kf2 Qf3  26.Ke1 Rxe3 27.Qf8  Kxf8 28.Rxe3 Qxe3  29.Kf1 Qf3  30.Ke1 Re8  31.Kd2 Re2  32.Kd1 Qf1#
moves.27... Qxh2+:
Gobbling pawns is another way to compensate for the sacrifice.
White gives up at this point - probably premature. The possible continuation 28.Re2 Qxg3 29. Re1 Qxf4  30.Kc2 is a very sharp and uncertain position

gameName: Europe v. Rest of the World Tournament
